results.title: A Race of horses
results.creator_credit: Kit Denton, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows without commentary the breeding and training of racehorses in Australia. Includes scenes of foaling, breaking-in and handling the young horses, and an actual race sequence. Photographed by renown cameraman Dean Semler.

results.title: The Queen in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The Queen in Australia is a landmark in Australian history. It not only records the first visit by a reigning monarch to Australia, it was also the first colour, feature-length documentary made in this country. This historic program provides nationwide coverage of the 1954 Royal Tour by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh - a two-month journey that took in every facet of Australian life: garden parties at Government House, dancers at the Tivoli, racing at Randwick, tennis at Kooyong with Rosewall and Hoad, cricket with the Don, even a meeting with Papua New Guinean tribal chiefs. The young royals visited every state in the nation, and the result is a remarkable and revealing insight into our nation in the 1950s.

results.title: Project: Public Service
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Commonwealth Public Service as seen through the eyes of a school-boy preparing a project book on the work of the Service. The film also briefly outlines the functioning of the parliamentary system and role of the public servants.

results.title: Power from the snow
results.creator_credit: Gunnar Isakson, John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A survey of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme. Shows the commencement of work in 1949, surveying the area and design of the first part of the project. Culminates in the official opening by the Prime Minister of the new Munyang Power Station, a few miles downstream from Guthega Dam which supplies it with water. Work continues on this great project, estimated to take twenty-five years to complete. Over an area of 3,000 square miles, men and machines reshape the land to supply Australia with light, and power.

results.title: The Pictures that moved: Australian cinema 1896-1920
results.creator_credit: Alan Anderson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “History of Australian Cinema Series”.
Show the intense activity in the Australian film industry from the first screening at the Melbourne Opera House in 1896 to the decline of the industry in the early 1920’s. Extracts from productions of particular interest are shown, including “Soldiers of the cross”, “Living Hawthorn”, “The Story of the Kelly gang”, “A Girl of the bush”, “On our selection” and “The Sentimental bloke”, with stills, contemporary press reports and interviews. Shows the technical advances gained, and the exhibition of the national character in a wide range of films. Shows the running of the first filmed Melbourne Cup in 1896 and a finals game of VFL at the Melbourne Cricket Ground between South Melbourne and Carlton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Anderson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Perth
results.creator_credit: Henry Lewes, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
A pictorial story with minimum commentary on the city of Perth. The daily newspaper is used as the medium to reflect, social, business and sporting activities of the average Australian family living in the city of Perth.
